book.title: De iuris arte, methodo, et praeceptis

marginalia.translation:
Grammar. 1. External or by speech. { } Style. General or common. { Rhetoric. 2. Form [of Digest]. { Internal or by reason. { Logic. 3. } Method.
Special or particular. { Nomological or legal. { The law itself, its soul, reason. 4. { that which is to be deliberated. that which is to be settled.
1.2. Lorenzo Valla wonderfully praises the style in the preface of the third book of the 'Elegancies'. 3. Pierre Gregoire, Doctor of Canon and Civil Law, examines and discusses the method in chapter two of 'De iuris arte, methodo, et praeceptis'. There, generally speaking, he takes this approach. We can certainly defend the order of the body of the 'Digest' in some way, but not in truth by that reasoning, because the 'De Arte' has been rearranged. For many things can (and should) be placed more appropriately than as they are set down there. Besides, they are familiar from the reasoned order established by those who stitched together the law. Add here the judgement of Dr Thomas Smith in the 'Legal Preface'.
Likewise, Francois Douaren, book one of 'Disputationum anniversariarum libri duo', chapter 55, where he agrees with the order and method of the 'Digest', refuting the innovators, who busy themselves with amending this method.
